title: Taiwan: Second Citi Future Leaders Development Program Awards Ceremony
summary: Taiwan - The CommonWealth Magazine Education Foundation and Citi Foundation awarded winners of the second Citi Future Leaders Development Program at Tainan First Senior High School on Sunday, March 31. Three student volunteer teams from Northern, Central and Southern Taiwan were lauded for their commitment to service and growth in personal development. A total of 650 students had registered nationwide to form 50 competing teams.
tag-1: Taiwan: Second Citi Future Leaders Development Program Awards Ceremony
tag-2: Taiwan – The CommonWealth Magazine Education Foundation and Citi Foundation awarded winners of the second Citi Future Leaders Development Program at Tainan First Senior High School on Sunday, March 31. Three student volunteer teams from Northern, Central and Southern Taiwan were lauded for their commitment to service and growth in personal development. A total of 650 students had registered nationwide to form 50 competing teams.
tag-3: Launched in 2011, the Citi Future Leaders Development Program was introduced to strengthen senior and vocational high school students' future academic and career prospects. The program encourages students to take on community service projects at neighboring elementary schools, tribal schools, libraries and orphanages.
tag-4: For the winning Nangang Zhuyuan team from Tainan First Senior High School, the Citi Future Leaders Development Program was a lesson in learning to respect and appreciate diversity when facing people of different cultures. Team leader Chang Chen-yen said, "It's not that we offered a service to them, it's Taiwu that gave us the opportunity to learn."
tag-5: Tseng I Ching from the winning group from Chang Gung University of Science and Technology added, "Through service, I have understood that cooperation among team members is one of the secrets to facilitating a smooth project." From the 'Better and Better' team from Stella Matutina Girls' High School in Taichung, Lin Yu-hsuan said," We are excited to pass down the experience!"
tag-6: Citibank Taiwan's Head of Country Corporate Affairs Michelle Liao praised the students' spirit and contribution.
tag-7: "In this diversified society, most students fare similarly well academically. Therefore, the key to stand out lies in other capabilities, including organizational and analysis capabilities, the ability and passion to gather resources and developing one's expertise to exert a positive influence on society. As the old saying goes, 'Life is expanded through sharing, and dreams are extended through giving.' I would like to encourage all students to enhance their strength and capabilities while at school – 'Learning by Doing' as the motto goes. By doing public service, not only can you benefit others, it is also the best investment you can make to prepare yourselves for the future," said Ms. Liao.
tag-8: Secretary-general of the CommonWealth Magazine Education Foundation Cathy Ling said, "The questionnaires collected from the students who joined project reveal that as much as 92 percent of interviewees believe that participating in the service project has enhanced their employment preparations in the future, including teamwork skills, communication capabilities and leadership. We believe the project can help young people identify their potential. We welcome more senior and vocational high school students to sign up for the Citi Future Leaders Development Program."
tag-9: Over the past two years, the Citi Future Leaders Development Program has seen more than 1,000 students come together to improve their team-building skills, cultivate a passion for community service and identify values to which they relate.
tag-10: The third Citi Future Leaders Development Program is now open for registration. Senior and vocational high school students nationwide are welcomed to sign up as teams. Detailed information can be found at http://futureleader.cw.com.tw/.
